elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Htzpya, Hatzpa, Hpytza were selected to be reacted with different Eu3+ salts under different pH, and four new compounds were obtained. Counter anion and pH are important in the self assembly of such compounds. The luminescence shows both intraligand and characteristic peaks of Eu3+.

elements.clean_text:
Htzpya, Hatzpa and Hpytza and their Eu3+ compounds were prepared.

The structures are controlled by the counter anion or pH value.

These compounds show both intraligand luminescence and characteristic peaks of Eu3+.

Abstract

Counter anion and pH play important roles in the self-assembly process of coordination compounds. Tetrazole carboxylate ligands are outstanding candidates for construction of coordination architectures. Four new compounds based on Htzpya, Hatzpa, Hpytza and europium(III) salts, namely mononuclear [Eu(tzpya)2(H2O)5]Cl⋅4H2O (1), binuclear [Eu2(atzpa)4(H2O)8](NO3)2⋅2H2O (2), one dimensional [Eu(pytza)3(H2O)2] n ⋅2nH2O (3) and [Eu(pytza)2(H2O)4] n Cl n  (4) were obtained, where Htzpya=3-(5-tetrazolyl)pyridine-1-acetic acid, Hatzpa=5-aminotetrazole-1-propanoic acid and Hpytza=5-(4-pyridyl) tetrazole-2-acetic acid. Different europium(III) salts EuX 3⋅6H2O (X =Cl-, NO3 -) and pH values were selected to investigate the influence of both the counter anions and the pH on the formation of such compounds. Furthermore, the luminescence properties of 1-4 in the solid state were also investigated at room temperature, showing both intraligand emission and characteristic peaks of Eu3+ for compounds 1-4.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The molecular architectures of the coordination compounds are affected by many factors, such as the solvent system, pH, counter anion , it is achievable to construct unexpected coordination architectures by changing these factors. Counter anions with appropriate steric hindrance may exist in the molecule because they are able to balance the charge while pH can affect the coordination ability of some certain ligands, carboxylate ligands, for instance. Therefore, different coordination architectures may be constructed by changing the counter anion and pH. Over the past decades, considerable attention given to lanthanide coordination compounds arises from either the intriguing structure topologies or the potential application as multifunctional materials, ranging from tunable luminescence, homogeneous catalysis to magnetism . For a long time, tetrazole ligands are excellent ligands to coordinate to metal centers because of the strong ability of nitrogen atoms . According to the hard and soft acid and base theory (HSAB), however, nitrogen atoms are less likely to connect with lanthanide ions. It may be a wise strategy to introduce a carboxylate group onto the tetrazole ring since oxygen atom is easy to coordinate with lanthanide ions. Tetrazole-carboxylate with both nitrogen and oxygen atoms are outstanding building blocks, the selection of such ligands arises from the following reasons: (i) oxygen and nitrogen are universally acknowledged as atoms with outstanding coordination ability; (ii) these ligands with either rigid tetrazole rings and flexible carboxylate groups may exhibit diverse coordination modes, thus forming various structures; (iii) the rich nitrogen and oxygen atoms can take part in the formation of hydrogen bonds and this can stabilize the supramolecular assemblies. In our previous work, we have reported the synthesis of mononuclear [<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>(tzpya)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]Cl·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:italic>Ln</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Y, Pr, Dy) (tzpya<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3-(5-tetrazolyl)pyridine-1-acetato) , one dimensional [Mn(atzpa)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (atzpa<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-aminotetrazole-1-propanoic anion) , three dimensional [<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Mn, Zn, Co) and the energetic performance of [Co(pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] , two dimensional [Pr<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>Cl]Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  (pytza<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-acetato). To extend our previous work, in this paper, Htzpya, Hatzpa and Hpytza were chosen to be reacted with Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> salts. Exploration of Eu(III)-tetrazole-carboxylate compounds may not only enrich the knowledge of coordination chemistry but also explore potential candidates for luminescence because Eu(III) compounds usually show characteristic peaks of the Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> and exhibit green luminescence. To systematically investigate the influence of the counter anion and pH on formation of such compounds, different counter anions (Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) and pH values were used. Additionally, the luminescence in the solid state were investigated, exhibiting both ligand centered emission and characteristic peaks of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The molecular architectures of the coordination compounds are affected by many factors, such as the solvent system, pH, counter anion , it is achievable to construct unexpected coordination architectures by changing these factors. Counter anions with appropriate steric hindrance may exist in the molecule because they are able to balance the charge while pH can affect the coordination ability of some certain ligands, carboxylate ligands, for instance. Therefore, different coordination architectures may be constructed by changing the counter anion and pH. Over the past decades, considerable attention given to lanthanide coordination compounds arises from either the intriguing structure topologies or the potential application as multifunctional materials, ranging from tunable luminescence, homogeneous catalysis to magnetism . For a long time, tetrazole ligands are excellent ligands to coordinate to metal centers because of the strong ability of nitrogen atoms . According to the hard and soft acid and base theory (HSAB), however, nitrogen atoms are less likely to connect with lanthanide ions. It may be a wise strategy to introduce a carboxylate group onto the tetrazole ring since oxygen atom is easy to coordinate with lanthanide ions. Tetrazole-carboxylate with both nitrogen and oxygen atoms are outstanding building blocks, the selection of such ligands arises from the following reasons: (i) oxygen and nitrogen are universally acknowledged as atoms with outstanding coordination ability; (ii) these ligands with either rigid tetrazole rings and flexible carboxylate groups may exhibit diverse coordination modes, thus forming various structures; (iii) the rich nitrogen and oxygen atoms can take part in the formation of hydrogen bonds and this can stabilize the supramolecular assemblies. In our previous work, we have reported the synthesis of mononuclear [Ln(tzpya)2(H2O)5]Cl⋅4H2O (Ln =Y, Pr, Dy) (tzpya=3-(5-tetrazolyl)pyridine-1-acetato) , one dimensional [Mn(atzpa)2(H2O)2] (atzpa=5-aminotetrazole-1-propanoic anion) , three dimensional [M(pytza)2] (M =Mn, Zn, Co) and the energetic performance of [Co(pytza)2] , two dimensional [Pr4(4-pytza)5(OH)4(H2O)7Cl]Cl2⋅4H2O  (pytza=5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-acetato). To extend our previous work, in this paper, Htzpya, Hatzpa and Hpytza were chosen to be reacted with Eu3+ salts. Exploration of Eu(III)-tetrazole-carboxylate compounds may not only enrich the knowledge of coordination chemistry but also explore potential candidates for luminescence because Eu(III) compounds usually show characteristic peaks of the Eu3+ and exhibit green luminescence. To systematically investigate the influence of the counter anion and pH on formation of such compounds, different counter anions (Cl-, NO3 -) and pH values were used. Additionally, the luminescence in the solid state were investigated, exhibiting both ligand centered emission and characteristic peaks of Eu3+.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and apparatus</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Htzpya, Hpytza and Hatzpa were prepared according to the literature method . The brief synthetic routine was proposed in . Other chemicals were commercially available reagents of analytical grade and were used without further purification. The IR spectra were obtained with a NICOLET380 spectrometer using KBr disks in the range of 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The elemental analysis for C, H and N were obtained on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 microanalyzer. Photoluminescence analyses were performed with an F-4600 fluorescence spectrometer. elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and apparatus

Htzpya, Hpytza and Hatzpa were prepared according to the literature method . The brief synthetic routine was proposed in . Other chemicals were commercially available reagents of analytical grade and were used without further purification. The IR spectra were obtained with a NICOLET380 spectrometer using KBr disks in the range of 4000-400cm-1. The elemental analysis for C, H and N were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 microanalyzer. Photoluminescence analyses were performed with an F-4600 fluorescence spectrometer. Single crystal X-ray diffraction was carried out with a Rigaku SCXmini-CCD diffractometer.

Synthesis of [Eu(tzpya)2(H2O)5]Cl⋅4H2O (1)

X-ray diffraction analysis

Suitable single crystals of complexes 1-4 were mounted on a RigakuSCXmini-CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at 291-296K. All absorption corrections were performed using the Crystal-Clear programs . The crystal structures of 1-4 were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms . For compounds 1-4, important crystal data and collection and refinement parameters are summarized in , selected bond lengths and angles are given in  and the hydrogen-bonding arrangement is listed in  (See   and  ).

<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>. Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> could only be obtained when EuCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was used in the relatively lower pH value (pH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions

Syntheses consideration and general characterization

In this paper, we have selected three different kinds of tetrazole-carboxylic acids ligands Hpytza, Hatzpa, Htzpya with both flexible carboxylate groups and rigid tetrazole rings to construct coordination architectures with Eu3+. A systematic study of the influence of pH and counter anion was shown in Table. To investigate the effect of the pH, we changed the pH from 3 to 6. In addition, different counter anions (Cl-, NO3 -) were applied to explore whether or not the counter anion would have an effect on the crystal structures of such compounds. Compound 1 can only be obtained when EuCl3⋅6H2O was used, this was confirmed by the existence of the Cl- in the resulting molecule. Crystals with the same cell parameters as those of compound 1 would also form while the pH changed from 3 to 6, showing the compound are not sensitive to the pH. Similarly, NO3 - contributes to the formation of compound 2 while the pH has a little influence on the formation of compound 2. Compound 3, however, are mainly influenced by the pH rather than the counter anion since the change of the counter anions all led to the formation of this compound, regardless of Cl- or NO3 -. Compound 4 could only be obtained when EuCl3⋅6H2O was used in the relatively lower pH value (pH=3).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are stable towards oxygen and moisture. Strong absorption around the region of 1618–1666<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in IR spectra are ascribed to the asymmetric vibration of the carboxylate group while those at 3208–3420<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> can be attributed to the O–H stretching vibration of the water molecules. The symmetric vibration of the carboxylate group, however, may be overlapped by the peaks of the tetrazole rings. The identities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are confirmed by X-ray crystallography.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1-4 are stable towards oxygen and moisture. Strong absorption around the region of 1618-1666cm-1 in IR spectra are ascribed to the asymmetric vibration of the carboxylate group while those at 3208-3420cm-1 for compounds 1-4 can be attributed to the O-H stretching vibration of the water molecules. The symmetric vibration of the carboxylate group, however, may be overlapped by the peaks of the tetrazole rings. The identities of 1-4 are confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

<ce:section-title id="st070">Description of crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st075">Crystal Structure of [Eu(tzpya)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]Cl·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic lattice space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, the Eu(III) center is nine-coordinate by five oxygen atoms from five water molecules (O3, O4, O4A, O5, O5A) and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups (O1, O1A, O2, O2A), forming a tricapped trigonal prism coordination arrangement. The Eu–O distances ranging from 2.409(2) to 2.528(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å is in good accordance with those of the previously reported Eu(III) compounds . Compared with [Eu(3-pytza)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (3-pytza<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-(3-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-actato, the isomer of tzpya) in which 3-pytza chelates one Eu(III) ion via two carboxylate-O atoms while simultaneously binds to a second Eu(III) ion via one carboxylate-O atom , each tzpya acts as a bidentate ligand to chelate one Eu(III) center via its carboxylate groups. Furthermore, neighboring mononuclear units are held together by hydrogen bonds to form a 3D supramolecular network. ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of crystal structures

Crystal Structure of [Eu(tzpya)2(H2O)5]Cl⋅4H2O (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic lattice space group C2/c. As shown in  , the Eu(III) center is nine-coordinate by five oxygen atoms from five water molecules (O3, O4, O4A, O5, O5A) and four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups (O1, O1A, O2, O2A), forming a tricapped trigonal prism coordination arrangement. The Eu-O distances ranging from 2.409(2) to 2.528(2)Å is in good accordance with those of the previously reported Eu(III) compounds . Compared with [Eu(3-pytza)2Cl(H2O)2] n  (3-pytza=5-(3-pyridyl)tetrazole-2-actato, the isomer of tzpya) in which 3-pytza chelates one Eu(III) ion via two carboxylate-O atoms while simultaneously binds to a second Eu(III) ion via one carboxylate-O atom , each tzpya acts as a bidentate ligand to chelate one Eu(III) center via its carboxylate groups. Furthermore, neighboring mononuclear units are held together by hydrogen bonds to form a 3D supramolecular network. ().

Each Eu(III) center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four water molecules (O5, O6, O7, O8) and five oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups (O1, O3, O1A, O2A, O4A), generating a EuO<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> tricapped trigonal prism coordination arrangement. Two neighboring Eu(III) centers are tetra-bridged by four carboxylate groups, where two ones adopt a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>

It is worthwhile to point out that the nitrate anion plays the role of balancing the charge rather than a choloride anion, this may be caused by the different counter anion. elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [Eu2(atzpa)4(H2O)8](NO3)2⋅2H2O (2)

The X-ray analysis demonstrates that compound 2 crystallizes in triclinic space group   P   1   ¯    . As shown in  . Each Eu(III) center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four water molecules (O5, O6, O7, O8) and five oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups (O1, O3, O1A, O2A, O4A), generating a EuO9 tricapped trigonal prism coordination arrangement. Two neighboring Eu(III) centers are tetra-bridged by four carboxylate groups, where two ones adopt a μ 1,1,3-COO coordination mode and the other two ones in a μ 1,3-COO syn-syn mode, respectively, thereby giving a binuclear structure. It is worthwhile to point out that the nitrate anion plays the role of balancing the charge rather than a choloride anion, this may be caused by the different counter anion. The Eu-O distances from 2.379(3) to 2.583(3)Å are in agreement with those of the analogous compounds . Adjacent [Eu2(atzpa)4(H2O)8]2+ binuclear units are held together to generate a three dimensional network ().

</mml:math> and the asymmetric unit also contains half of the molecule. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, each Eu(III) center is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, two of which (O5B, O7) are from two water molecules and six come from five carboxylate groups (O2, O3, O4B, O5, O5B, O6B) and one nitrogen atom (N15A) from pyridyl ring, forming a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry. Neighboring Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> are doubly bridged by two pytza ligands in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-COO <ce:italic>syn-syn</ce:italic> mode to form a binuclear unit; Adjacent binuclear units are also doubly bridged by four tetra-dentate pytza anions <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> nitrogen atom of the pyridyl ring and the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group in a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1,1,3</ce:inf>-COO mode, thereby giving a one dimensional ladder like chain extending along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (

The Eu–O distances ranges from 2.3605(14) to 2.5993(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are correspondent to those of the previously reported Eu(III) ligands . Hpytza is the isomer of Htzpya, however, the structure of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is quite different from that of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. This can be explained by the fact that the different positions of the carboxylate group have a fundamental effect on the formation of such compounds. elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Eu(pytza)3(H2O)2] n ⋅2nH2O (3)

The X-ray analysis reveals that compound 3 crystallizes in triclinic space group   P   1   ¯     and the asymmetric unit also contains half of the molecule. As shown in  , each Eu(III) center is coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, two of which (O5B, O7) are from two water molecules and six come from five carboxylate groups (O2, O3, O4B, O5, O5B, O6B) and one nitrogen atom (N15A) from pyridyl ring, forming a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry. Neighboring Eu3+ are doubly bridged by two pytza ligands in a μ 1,3-COO syn-syn mode to form a binuclear unit; Adjacent binuclear units are also doubly bridged by four tetra-dentate pytza anions via nitrogen atom of the pyridyl ring and the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group in a μ 1,1,3-COO mode, thereby giving a one dimensional ladder like chain extending along the c axis ( ). The Eu-O distances ranges from 2.3605(14) to 2.5993(15)Å, which are correspondent to those of the previously reported Eu(III) ligands . Hpytza is the isomer of Htzpya, however, the structure of compound 3 is quite different from that of compound 1. This can be explained by the fact that the different positions of the carboxylate group have a fundamental effect on the formation of such compounds. Furthermore, neighboring one dimensional chains are linked together by hydrogen bonds to form a 3D supramolecular network ().

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of [Eu(pytza)2(H2O)4] n Cl n  (4)

The asymmetric unit of compound 4 consists of two pytza ligands, four coordinated water molecules with triclinic lattice space group   P   1   ¯    . As shown in  , each Eu(III) center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four water molecules (O5, O6, O7, O8) and four oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups (O1, O3, O2A, O4B), forming a distorted square antiprism coordination arrangement. Each pytza in acts as a bidentate ligand to bridge two adjacent Eu(III) centers in a μ 1,3-COO syn-anti mode, thereby forming a one dimensional zigzag chain extending along the a axis with Eu⋯Eu distance of 4.9247Å and Eu⋯Eu⋯Eu angle of 143.945(31)° ( ). Compared with compound 3, there is only one coordination mode found in compound 4. It is interesting that no counter anion was observed in compound 4 since pytza itself plays the role of balancing the charge. Adjacent 1D chains are held together by hydrogen bonds to form a 3D supramolecular network ().

The luminescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and the free ligands were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As is shown in

Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> all exhibit five peaks upon excitations at 307, 382, 375 and 375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively (

The peaks at 412<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 444<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 453<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 448<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, are assigned to the ligand centered emission because similar emissions of the corresponding ligands are observed. Generally, the intraligand fluorescence emission wavelength is determined by the energy gap between the π and π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> molecular orbitals of the free ligand, which is related to the extent of π conjugation . The other four peaks are ascribed to the characteristic peaks of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, which belong to the transitions of <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties

Lanthanide coordination compounds are well known for their excellent luminescence behaviors. The luminescence properties of 1-4 and the free ligands were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As is shown in  , the free ligands Htzpya, Hpytza and Hatzpa exhibit maximum emissions at 360, 393, and 433nm upon excitations at 315, 327 and 371nm, respectively. Compounds 1-4 all exhibit five peaks upon excitations at 307, 382, 375 and 375nm, respectively ( ). The peaks at 412nm for 1, 444nm for 2, 453nm for 3, 448nm for 4, are assigned to the ligand centered emission because similar emissions of the corresponding ligands are observed. Generally, the intraligand fluorescence emission wavelength is determined by the energy gap between the π and π∗ molecular orbitals of the free ligand, which is related to the extent of π conjugation . The other four peaks are ascribed to the characteristic peaks of Eu3+, which belong to the transitions of 5D0 → 7F J  (J =1-4). For 1-4, characteristic peaks of Eu3+ are assigned to the transitions of 5D0 → 7F1 (593nm for 1, 594nm for 2, 595nm for 3 and 594nm for 4), 5D0 → 7F2 (612nm for 1, 619nm for 2 and 3, 618nm for 4), 5D0 → 7F3 (650nm for 1, 651nm for 2 and 4, 652nm for 3) and 5D0 → 7F4 (701nm for 1, 699nm for 2 and 4, 698nm for 3) transitions . 5D0 → 7F1 can be ascribed to a magnetic dipole transition whose intensity should vary with the crystal field strength acting on the Eu(III) ion. The emission intensity of 5D0 → 7F2, an electric dipole transition, increases as the site symmetry of the Eu(III) ions decreases. The coordination environment of Eu3+ in compounds 1-4 are almost symmetric since the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 (electric dipole) is similar to that of 5D0 → 7F1 (magnetic dipole) , which is confirmed by crystallographic analysis.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st100">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In summary, Eu(III) coordination compounds with the ligands Htzpya, Hpytza and Hatzpa are herein reported for the first time. Our research shows the structures of such compounds are partly controlled by the different counter anions or pH values. These compounds are self assembled to form three dimensional network structures by hydrogen bonds. Furthermore, the luminescence properties show both intraligand emission and characteristic peaks of Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>. The structural diversity of such compounds can be achieved by changing the reaction conditions. We are currently investigating other compounds based on tetrazole carboxylate ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, Eu(III) coordination compounds with the ligands Htzpya, Hpytza and Hatzpa are herein reported for the first time. Our research shows the structures of such compounds are partly controlled by the different counter anions or pH values. These compounds are self assembled to form three dimensional network structures by hydrogen bonds. Furthermore, the luminescence properties show both intraligand emission and characteristic peaks of Eu3+. The structural diversity of such compounds can be achieved by changing the reaction conditions. We are currently investigating other compounds based on tetrazole carboxylate ligands.

<ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of [Eu(tzpya)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]Cl·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Htzpya (0.041<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in water (1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and the pH value was adjusted to 3, 4, 5 or 6 with KOH (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M), then EuCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.0366<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and ethanol (3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) were added to the solution, which was sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, slow evaporation gave rise to the formation of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, yield: 34% based on Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>ClEuN<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>: C, 25.36; H, 3.99; N, 18.48. Found: C, 25.03; H, 3.90; N, 18.76%. Synthesis of [Eu(tzpya)2(H2O)5]Cl⋅4H2O (1)

Htzpya (0.041g, 0.2mmol) was dissolved in water (1.0mL) and the pH value was adjusted to 3, 4, 5 or 6 with KOH (0.2M), then EuCl3⋅6H2O (0.0366g, 0.1mmol) and ethanol (3.0mL) were added to the solution, which was sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 120°C for 48h. After the sample was cooled to room temperature, slow evaporation gave rise to the formation of compound 1. For 1, yield: 34% based on Eu3+. Anal. Calc. for C16H30ClEuN10O13: C, 25.36; H, 3.99; N, 18.48. Found: C, 25.03; H, 3.90; N, 18.76%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3392(s), 1654(m), 1557(w), 1526(w), 1438(w), 1407(m), 1307(w), 1201(w), 1142(w), 1047(w), 694(m), 616(m), 486(m).

Synthesis of [Eu2(atzpa)4(H2O)8](NO3)2⋅2H2O (2)

A similar method to that of compound 1 was adopted to prepare 2 except that Htzpya and EuCl3⋅6H2O were replaced by Hatzpa and Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O, respectively. Colorless block crystals 2 were obtained. For 2, yield: 35% based on Eu3+. Anal. Calc. for C24H26EuN15O10: C, 34.46; H, 3.13; N, 25.12. Found: C, 34.03; H, 3.20; N, 25.66%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3365(s), 3208(s), 2365(m), 1666(s), 1592(m), 1486(w), 1451(w), 1401(w), 1339(m), 1229(m), 1108(m), 1014(w), 944(w).

Synthesis of [Eu(pytza)3(H2O)2] n ⋅2nH2O (3) and [Eu(pytza)2(H2O)4] n ⋅Cl n  (4)

Hpytza (0.0402g, 0.2mmol) was dissloved in water (1.0mL) and the pH value was adjusted to approximate 6 with KOH (0.2M), then EuCl3⋅6H2O (0.0366g, 0.1mmol) or Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.0446g, 0.1mmol) and ethanol (3.0mL) were added to the solution, which was sealed in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 120°C for 48h. Colorless block crystals of 3 were obtained. For 3, yield: 43% based on Eu3+. Anal. Calc. for C16H44Eu2N22O24: C, 15.59; H, 3.60; N, 25.00. Found: C, 14.93; H, 3.44; N, 25.66%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3420(s), 1664(s), 1618(s), 1460(m), 1388(s), 1303(m), 820(m), 752(m), 727(m), 699(m), 672(m), 590(m). A similar method to that of compound 3 was adopted to prepare 4 except that pH was adjusted to approximately 3 and EuCl3⋅6H2O (0.0366g, 0.1mmol) was used. Colorless block crystals 4 were obtained. For 4, yield: 43% based on Eu3+. Anal. Calc. for C16H20ClEuN10O8: C, 28.78; H, 3.02; N, 20.97. Found: C, 28.03; H, 3.13; N, 20.66%. IR (KBr,cm-1): 3420(s), 1664(s), 1618(s), 1460(m), 1388(s), 1303(m), 820(m), 752(m), 727(m), 699(m), 672(m), 590(m).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties

Lanthanide coordination compounds are well known for their excellent luminescence behaviors. The luminescence properties of 1-4 and the free ligands were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As is shown in  , the free ligands Htzpya, Hpytza and Hatzpa exhibit maximum emissions at 360, 393, and 433nm upon excitations at 315, 327 and 371nm, respectively. Compounds 1-4 all exhibit five peaks upon excitations at 307, 382, 375 and 375nm, respectively ( ). The peaks at 412nm for 1, 444nm for 2, 453nm for 3, 448nm for 4, are assigned to the ligand centered emission because similar emissions of the corresponding ligands are observed. Generally, the intraligand fluorescence emission wavelength is determined by the energy gap between the π and π∗ molecular orbitals of the free ligand, which is related to the extent of π conjugation . The other four peaks are ascribed to the characteristic peaks of Eu3+, which belong to the transitions of 5D0 → 7F J  (J =1-4). For 1-4, characteristic peaks of Eu3+ are assigned to the transitions of 5D0 → 7F1 (593nm for 1, 594nm for 2, 595nm for 3 and 594nm for 4), 5D0 → 7F2 (612nm for 1, 619nm for 2 and 3, 618nm for 4), 5D0 → 7F3 (650nm for 1, 651nm for 2 and 4, 652nm for 3) and 5D0 → 7F4 (701nm for 1, 699nm for 2 and 4, 698nm for 3) transitions . 5D0 → 7F1 can be ascribed to a magnetic dipole transition whose intensity should vary with the crystal field strength acting on the Eu(III) ion. The emission intensity of 5D0 → 7F2, an electric dipole transition, increases as the site symmetry of the Eu(III) ions decreases. The coordination environment of Eu3+ in compounds 1-4 are almost symmetric since the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 (electric dipole) is similar to that of 5D0 → 7F1 (magnetic dipole) , which is confirmed by crystallographic analysis.
